quotes.topic_title: Mindset shift: reframing “pushback” at work
quotes.text: Pushback is, I couldn't imagine a word more viscerally that makes you feel like you're sort of physically going against what somebody else wants, and it gears people into a mindset of then, well, how should I push back.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Highlights how language (“pushback”) primes an adversarial stance before the conversation even begins.

quotes.topic_title: Mindset shift: reframing “pushback” at work
quotes.text: It starts from a place of I need to disagree, I need to say no.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concise diagnosis of the default mental model that makes disagreement less effective.

quotes.topic_title: Mindset shift: reframing “pushback” at work
quotes.text: It's a very negative mindset, purely based on the word that has come to label a behavior that alternatively could be about how do I shift the direction on something, or how do I help the business actually succeed when I disagree with somebody about something, and that's a very different mindset.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Reframes disagreement as a shared-success tool (direction-shifting and business outcomes), not interpersonal conflict.

quotes.topic_title: Mindset shift: reframing “pushback” at work
quotes.text: And so, the two things that I've seen be most successful would be, I think number one is actually understanding what a goal is or what somebody's kind of issue is with something, and then actually aligning those things in some way.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Gives a practical two-step method: uncover the underlying goal/issue, then align on it to resolve disagreement.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So, my career has all been about solving important problems in a unique way.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A simple career filter practitioners can use to choose roles/projects: importance of the problem + differentiated approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think the latter part is the youngest child in me who has to be special and do things different than other people, and the former is about making sure that my time is spent well since we're all limited there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A memorable mental model tying motivation (differentiation) to a constraint (limited time) for prioritizing what to work on.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I started my first company, much like a lot of teenagers, it was around test prep and getting people ready for college, and it was my first exposure to using technology at scale to help people, and I just found it addictive ever since.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concrete example of finding a durable career direction by noticing what kinds of work feel intrinsically compelling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Low and behold, I was at the world's largest productivity company at Microsoft, and most people there in my opinion were wildly unproductive and I wasn't shipping a lot.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about large organizations that can help practitioners anticipate and manage bureaucracy and shipping velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I moved to San Francisco without a job. I was really arrogant. I said, "I'll never work for anybody else," and then lo and behold, Yammer comes along, I'm super excited about it, I had been working on a product actually in the same space.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A specific career bet illustrating how proximity to a space you’re building in can create unexpected opportunities (and humility).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, we've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop. Think collect data, inform bets, ship experiments and learn.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concise end-to-end framework for product growth that links analytics to decision-making, experimentation, and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That's the heart of growth to us.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Reframes growth as a learning loop rather than a set of isolated tactics, emphasizing iteration and feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, the big aha was seeing how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach, and send data to other destinations.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical example of using observed customer workflows to guide product expansion and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experiment in CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Actionable product-development advice: let customer behavior and needs drive new product lines and features.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, Amplitude tries to meet customers where they are.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A customer-centric strategy principle that can guide onboarding, packaging, and product surface area decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Why they re-recorded: Web3 changed fast
quotes.text: by the time the podcast's supposed to come out, Web3, things have changed in the world of Web3, and so, it kind of felt a little stale and out of touch, and so, we decided let's do it again.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical reminder to revalidate content (or strategy) against fast-changing markets and be willing to redo work when it becomes outdated.

quotes.topic_title: Why they re-recorded: Web3 changed fast
quotes.text: So, my career has all been about solving important problems in a unique way.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A simple career decision framework: optimize for problem importance and differentiated approach.

quotes.topic_title: Why they re-recorded: Web3 changed fast
quotes.text: the former is about making sure that my time is spent well since we're all limited there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A prioritization lens for practitioners: treat time as the core constraint and choose work accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Why they re-recorded: Web3 changed fast
quotes.text: I actually got started in a sense in tech when I was 15. I started my first company, much like a lot of teenagers, it was around test prep and getting people ready for college, and it was my first exposure to using technology at scale to help people, and I just found it addictive ever since.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concrete example of finding product motivation early by using tech to help people at scale.

quotes.topic_title: State of Web3 during crypto winter
quotes.text: I genuinely believe Web3 is in the strongest position that it's ever been in.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A contrarian framing that separates underlying ecosystem strength from token price performance during a downturn.

quotes.topic_title: State of Web3 during crypto winter
quotes.text: the number of companies that I'm seeing be formed, the number of products that are starting to actually achieve some form of early product market fit, some products that are starting to scale.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A practical set of leading indicators (formation, early PMF, scaling) practitioners can use to assess a market beyond hype cycles.

quotes.topic_title: State of Web3 during crypto winter
quotes.text: a lot of new technologies don't move up in a straight line, and Web3 is especially challenging here because so many things have been financialized from the outset, whereas generally speaking, you'll see startups or new technologies mature over many years, whether it's the internet itself, artificial intelligence, QR codes, all sorts of things that kind of have gone through different periods of adoption,
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A mental model for expecting volatility and non-linear adoption—especially when financialization amplifies swings early.

quotes.topic_title: State of Web3 during crypto winter
quotes.text: I think we're seeing things kind of record Ethereum transactions happening, new Layer 2 technologies launching all the time that are going to help scale Layer 1 Blockchains, Solana has announced its phone that's going to be the first sort of Web3 native phone out there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Concrete examples of traction and scaling progress that can guide where builders focus (usage metrics, L2s, new form factors).

quotes.topic_title: Leading through downturns: morale via progress
quotes.text: So, in my opinion, I think that the only way to maintain moral is to make progress. I think that no speech, no sort of extrinsic motivators like we're going to give everybody some free crypto to keep motivated about it or something like that really works. I think people get really excited when they see progress.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A clear morale framework for downturns: motivation is driven by visible progress and shipping, not pep talks or incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Leading through downturns: morale via progress
quotes.text: So, for example, at Alchemy, we see more developers than we've ever had on the platform today, and then we're shipping, we just launched Solana support and people are like, "This is real." We're actually doing things, building things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Concrete example of using traction (developer growth) and shipping (new support) to make progress tangible and restore belief.

quotes.topic_title: Leading through downturns: morale via progress
quotes.text: We saw this at Airbnb when the business had a draw down in revenue, and I know you'd covered this with Sanchan recently, right? It was 85, 90% revenue and you didn't know when it was going to turn around, right?
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A vivid downturn benchmark that underscores how extreme uncertainty can be—and why leadership tactics must work without a clear recovery timeline.

quotes.topic_title: Leading through downturns: morale via progress
quotes.text: But I think what worked was making progress and actually focusing on product and your customers, and ultimately if you hire the right people who are motivated for the right reasons, I think that recipe keeps people highly motivated and highly effective at building for when things do eventually turn around.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Actionable recipe for leading through downturns: focus on product/customers and hire mission-driven builders to sustain execution until recovery.

quotes.topic_title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
quotes.text: I actually am seeing things change a lot, and one thing in Web3, if one learns nothing is the ability to admit when they're wrong or when things change.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A practical mindset for operating in fast-changing markets: update beliefs quickly and explicitly when conditions shift.

quotes.topic_title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
quotes.text: So, basically, I'm specifically noticing a lot of teams hiring product leaders, more product managers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concrete signal that Web3 orgs are maturing: increased demand for PM leadership rather than purely engineering/community roles.

quotes.topic_title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
quotes.text: I also think the market is getting increasingly competitive. So, there's many NFT marketplaces. There's many Layer 1 and Layer 2 blockchains. As a result, I think product is always a competitive advantage, right? If it's working, it improves strategy, it improves execution, and improves team collaboration.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A clear competitive model: as categories crowd, strong product management becomes a differentiator through strategy, execution, and collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
quotes.text: maybe that was less of a difference maker before where these teams didn't need that competitive advantage as much because maybe they launched a token and the token was mooning, and so a bunch of people were adopting the product, but that only lasts so long, and first principles still come come in to focus, whether it's one day or one month from now.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that growth driven by token hype is temporary; fundamentals eventually determine product success.

quotes.topic_title: PMs in Web3: from optional to essential
quotes.text: something I find is that people that are kind of anti having a PM or don't see why they need a PM in my experience just haven't worked with a great product manager because my experience, you find a great PM, they just make everything better
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A diagnostic for PM skepticism: resistance often reflects lack of exposure to high-quality PM craft rather than a true absence of need.

quotes.topic_title: What surprised Jason most about Web3 products
quotes.text: I mean, I think that the biggest surprise to me, despite what we were just talking about, was how big some products have gotten without kind of the traditional either product manager role or without the playbooks that we're so used to from the last 20 years of the internet.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that traditional PM roles and established playbooks are required for products to reach massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: What surprised Jason most about Web3 products
quotes.text: And so, for example, Uniswap has done more daily volume on certain days than Coinbase, and Uniswap is about a hundred people versus 5,000-plus at Coinbase, right?
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scale and team-size comparison that highlights how lean Web3 teams can outperform Web2 incumbents on key metrics.

quotes.topic_title: What surprised Jason most about Web3 products
quotes.text: there's a ton of progress being made without some of the traditional product structure or individuals.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Suggests alternative organizational structures can still drive rapid product progress, prompting practitioners to rethink staffing and process requirements.

quotes.topic_title: What surprised Jason most about Web3 products
quotes.text: it's been incredibly surprising to see how far products can get without the product playbooks and resources that somebody who's worked in the internet space from the last 10 or 20 years is so used to.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Reinforces a counterintuitive takeaway: legacy internet-era product practices may not be prerequisites for success in emerging ecosystems.

quotes.topic_title: Which company shaped his product approach most
quotes.text: And so, people say Google is an engineering culture. People said Facebook is a product culture, Airbnb or Pinterest, sometimes a design culture or things like this, and I think that Amazon was a place where you couldn't divorce business and product. You couldn't be a product manager without thinking about revenue growth, without thinking about go to market, and I really like that because as a startup founder doing product in a bigger company, it gave me the chance to exercise a lot of those skills.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A clear mental model for how Amazon forces PMs to tie product decisions directly to business outcomes (revenue and GTM).

quotes.topic_title: Which company shaped his product approach most
quotes.text: I certainly had a positive experience, but I think that as you know and as I'm sure you've advised countless people, it's so context dependent. Are you learning the zero to one? Are you learning the one to scale? What's your aspiration? Is somebody trying to start a company eventually, or are they trying to work the ranks of the product leadership trajectory?
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Practical career decision framework: choose companies based on the specific learning mode (0→1 vs 1→scale) and your end goal.

quotes.topic_title: Which company shaped his product approach most
quotes.text: there's often a non-linear sort of correlation between factors that we traditionally think are linked, right? So, my time there was one of the shortest, but my learnings were some of the greatest because I was really intentional and maybe because of the sort of moment in time and what I wanted to get out of it.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that tenure length doesn’t predict learning impact—intentionality and timing can matter more.

quotes.topic_title: Which company shaped his product approach most
quotes.text: I think that's something I've noticed a lot is that a lot of the proxies don't necessarily match the internal realities in certain cases.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Warning against relying on surface-level proxies (like company stage/headcount) to predict culture and day-to-day experience.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
quotes.text: Every employee goes through actually like a business writing class after they start at Amazon. They give you a little card with five tips that you're supposed to keep on your desk about concision and specificity in the words you use.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Highlights Amazon’s institutionalized writing discipline as an operational mechanism for clearer thinking and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
quotes.text: For example, you should never write the word great in an Amazon press release. You should write user friendly in X, Y, Z way and will save customers time 20 minutes each day through this.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concrete rule-of-thumb that forces specificity and measurable claims over vague adjectives.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
quotes.text: It's funny, when people try to move from slides to docs, they really just import the same mindsets that they use in slides, but just with more words now.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that switching formats doesn’t improve clarity unless the underlying communication habits change.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
quotes.text: And so, I think I found that really useful in emails I write or documents I write to this day is just going over, not because you're saving ink by cutting words, but because it forces clarity of thought. Fewer words means every word is 10 pounds in weight instead of one, and that means that the decisions you're making, the trade offs are far more intentional,
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Explains why concision is a thinking tool (not a style preference): it increases the “cost” of each word and sharpens tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Amazon’s “working backwards” and writing discipline
quotes.text: So the structure of the PRFAQ docs was generally an introduction where you're announced the product, problem, solution, customer quote, leadership quote, and a call to action.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A reusable template practitioners can apply to write “working backwards” docs that align customer value, strategy, and rollout details.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
quotes.text: But nothing's above them, and a lot of founders or a lot of CEOs or even CPOs and leaders think you get to a certain point and then I'm above a product spec, I'm above looking at the data running a sequel query, and I think that that is a mistake in a lot of ways, especially from a standpoint of who people come to respect as well as efficacy at one's job.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that seniority shouldn’t exempt leaders from hands-on work, and that staying close to specs/data increases both respect and effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
quotes.text: leaders are... For example, when we were going to launch Prime, order a bunch of Prime things and see what happens and really test things out, and write up a long feedback email on Saturday or something like that, and make sure that things are moving forward.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for leadership-in-the-details: personally dogfood launches, document feedback, and drive follow-through.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
quotes.text: He actually ran the product reviews. It was the CEO of the company doing product reviews, not some kind of middle tier of a director of product who was just running them.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A specific operating model that raises quality and accountability by making product reviews a CEO-level mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
quotes.text: So, what I've seen is nothing is above them, they're in the details, and they adapt to new information and new situations.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A crisp three-part framework for great leadership: humility, detail orientation, and adaptability.

quotes.topic_title: Traits of great leaders: humility, details, adaptability
quotes.text: I think the biggest thing I take away from that is humility is that nothing is not my job, right? Anything, could be picking up paper off the floor and putting it in the trash, or it could be reviewing a product spec, whatever it is, and then begin the details in my opinion is about craft, right, and really understanding things at a low level such that you're able to reason about it and make good decisions
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A useful distinction between two often-confused traits—humility (“nothing is not my job”) vs. craft (deep understanding to make better decisions).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a very top-down approach to trying to drive results, but is opposed to a sense of accountability if you drove a sense of responsibility.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Highlights a leadership mental model: shifting from enforcing accountability to cultivating responsibility to drive better outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If people felt like this is my company too, this is my product, this is my office floor. I don't want trash on the floor. I'm going to pick it up and throw it there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A vivid example of ownership culture that practitioners can use to diagnose and build responsibility in teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: At Airbnb, I think people who felt that way were willing to push back on certain things, or they're willing to propose new ideas because they felt invested in the company.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Connects a sense of ownership to concrete behaviors—healthy dissent and idea generation—that improve decision quality and innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 10,000 people from Airbnb to Coinbase to Google to Tesla have taken courses from real experts and operators that have spent decades honing their craft.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals credibility and scale for cohort-based learning as a professional development lever.

quotes.topic_title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
quotes.text: I think a lot of leaders focus on accountability in an organization once they get large, and so, you see things like performance reviews and things like this. It's a very top-down approach to trying to drive results, but is opposed to a sense of accountability if you drove a sense of responsibility.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Contrasts top-down accountability mechanisms with cultivating responsibility as a more effective driver of results.

quotes.topic_title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
quotes.text: If people felt like this is my company too, this is my product, this is my office floor. I don't want trash on the floor. I'm going to pick it up and throw it there.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A vivid ownership mental model: treat the environment and product as yours, and act without waiting for assigned roles.

quotes.topic_title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
quotes.text: Even if we have somebody whose job it supposedly is to clean that up, it's like I take pride of ownership in this and I'm connected to it, and I think that makes all the difference in terms of...
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Highlights the practical behavior shift that comes from pride and connection—stepping beyond role boundaries.

quotes.topic_title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
quotes.text: At Airbnb, I think people who felt that way were willing to push back on certain things, or they're willing to propose new ideas because they felt invested in the company.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Specific example of how ownership culture enables constructive dissent and proactive innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Ownership culture: responsibility beats accountability
quotes.text: I see an engineer hop in and fix something at 3:00 AM because they feel committed to the code base, and it's not a thousand-person engineering organization where my only job is to make the iOS app 2% more effective at engaging users.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Concrete illustration of responsibility-driven behavior versus narrow, siloed optimization in large orgs.

quotes.topic_title: How to “push back” on CEOs: align on goals
quotes.text: pushback is, I couldn't imagine a word more viscerally that makes you feel like you're sort physically going against what somebody else wants, and it gears people into a mindset of then, well, how should I push back. It starts from a place of I need to disagree, I need to say no. It's a very negative mindset, purely based on the word that has come to label a behavior that alternatively could be about how do I shift the direction on something, or how do I help the business actually succeed when I disagree with somebody about something, and that's a very different mindset.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Reframes “pushback” as collaborative direction-shifting rather than adversarial disagreement, changing how you approach exec conflicts.

quotes.topic_title: How to “push back” on CEOs: align on goals
quotes.text: the two things that I've seen be most successful would be, I think number one is actually understanding what a goal is or what somebody's kind of issue is with something, and then actually aligning those things in some way.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: A practical method for influencing CEOs: uncover the real goal/concern and align your proposal to it.

quotes.topic_title: How to “push back” on CEOs: align on goals
quotes.text: And so, when we took a step back, it was reimagined as trip designers, not concierges, and their goal was to design your trip, and part of that meant a very elegant, simple chat experience so that you could have a efficient, fast, positive experience with that trip designer and move on.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Concrete Airbnb example of redefining the experience to simplify scope while improving customer value.

quotes.topic_title: How to “push back” on CEOs: align on goals
quotes.text: Founders are too smart, especially at all these companies we've talked about, to be fooled with a simple renaming of something. But I think the combination of a bigger idea, more exciting idea that was at the heart of what we were all going after together, combined with a simple way of communicating it because I've also seen big ideas that are poorly communicated fall flat on their face and not achieve the intended outcome. Those two together, I think were a really potent combination.
quotes.speaker: Jason Shah
quotes.context: Highlights that effective reframing requires both substantive vision and clear communication—not just “window dressing.”
